en.value: We are open 7 days a week.
Select an expression with a similar meaning to "yesterday evening" to complete the sentence.
The shop is closed at the moment.
[k]On[/k] Sunday all the shops are closed.
We use "at" to talk about a specific time.
Read and listen to the expression.
My meeting is at 10 a.m. today.
We're now going to learn about prepositions of time. They help us give the time at which something happens.
Select the word you can use with "on".
You can use "in" with months and years.
Can I have a table at 5 p.m. on Thursday?
I get up at 6 a.m. every morning.
Select the words that go with "on".
Read and listen to the expression and key phrase.
Can I book a table for 2 o'clock today, please?
Select the words that go with "at".
Select the word with a similar meaning to "this evening".
My birthday is on the 5th of October.
My interview is on Monday at 11 a.m.
Select the words that go with "in".
[k]It's quarter to nine|It is quarter to nine|It's quarter to 9|It is quarter to 9|It's eight forty-five|It is eight forty-five[/k].
Read and listen to the word and the key phrase.
We don't use a preposition with "next / last / this / every".
We also say "in the past" and "in the future".
Can I book a table for this afternoon, please?
Select the words in the correct order.
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
I get up [k]at[/k] 6 a.m. every morning.
Type another way of saying this sentence.
in the morning / in the afternoon / in the evening
This sentence is about something that is happening today.
We use the preposition "at" to discuss clock times, holidays and other specific time frames.
Type the preposition we use with specific days and holidays.
Sorry, the kitchen is closed [k]in[/k] [k]the[/k] afternoon.
Can I book a table for 2 o'clock [k]today[/k], please?
I'm busy at breakfast but I'm free at lunch.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
On my birthday we always go to a restaurant.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
We also say "at breakfast", "at lunch" and "at dinner".
Fill in the gap using the audio.
If we want to talk specifically about today, we can use the word "this" followed by "morning / afternoon / evening".
[k]It's half past four|It is half past four|It's four thirty|It is four thirty[/k].
I'd like to live in London in the future.

Did you know? In spoken English,"last night" and "yesterday evening" can mean the same thing. The same applies to "tonight" and "this evening". "Tonight / last night" are slightly more colloquial than "this evening / yesterday evening".
Can I book a table for 2 o'clock [k]today[/k], please?
Excuse me. What time is it?
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Giving the time of day, talking about other time periods - Prepositions of time
Select the answer you hear in the audio.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Type the preposition we use with months and years.
We can use some of these words together to talk about other periods of time in the past and in the future. Look at the examples below. Can you spot the exception to the rule?
What do you do in the evening?
We use "on" with specific dates and days of week.
Match each time period with the right preposition.
What do you usually do [k]on[/k] Valentine's Day?
Can we meet [k]on[/k] Monday at 5 p.m.?
What do you do [k]in the evening[/k]?
Imagine you're booking a table. Say when you'd like to book for.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
What time do they open this morning?
The shop is closed this afternoon.
In English, we use the 12-hour, or "meridiem", clock. This means that we separate our day into two twelve-hour sections.
Match the beginning and the end of the sentences.
What are you doing this evening?
You've just learned how to give an exact time of day, but there are lots of other helpful words and phrases we can use to express periods of time. Here are some that we'll learn in this unit.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
What are you doing Friday night?
Sorry, the kitchen is closed in the afternoon.
Fill in the gap using the image.
We say "today" to talk about the current day. What do we say to talk about the current or coming night?
This unit is the first of two units on telling the time. We'll learn things like:
Select the word which means "yesterday" in this context.
We use the preposition "on" with days of the week or any specific dates.
We use the preposition "in" with months, seasons, years and longer periods of time.
On my birthday we usually go to a restaurant.
Select the preposition that we use with specific dates and holidays.
The shop is closed tonight. = The shop is closed this evening.
The words "to" and "past" indicate whether a time is before or after the hour. Look at the examples below.
Here's a list of the words and expressions we've just learned:
It's my birthday in two weeks!
I stay with my family at Christmas.
This weekend we go on holiday.
Here are some other ways to talk about when something happens. Notice that we don't use prepositions with these words.
What did you do last night? = What did you do yesterday evening?
